chunks.en: Why does Windows have a long standby time, and then the response becomes very laggy when operating again?
I am currently using the Win10 system. My computer is a Lenovo Xiaoxin Rui 7000 released in 2017 with 16G of memory.

Recently, I always find that when it has been in standby for a day or more, when I operate again, such as opening a folder or typing, there will be a noticeable lag, and it will always take a few seconds to respond. It feels unsmooth, but it is still smooth after restarting.
I'm curious why this is. How should I look at it from a technical perspective?
@sir283 In my personal experience, the experience of using Linux on a laptop can only be described as disastrous.
The strongest is the screen scaling ratio, which almost does not support customization.
Secondly, Linux's power management strategy is almost a mystery, and opening performance mode can cause the screen to freeze at any time.
One possible reason is handle leakage.
The original poster can open the task manager and check how many handles the system currently has on the "Performance" page.
If the number is too large (for example, more than 300,000), it is possible that a certain process has a handle leak.

In the "Details" page, you can also sort the processes according to the number of handles to see which process handle is leaking. Generally, restarting the corresponding process will solve the problem.
Handle leakage is very common.
For example, starting around 2019, explorer.exe leaks a registry handle every time you right-click in an open folder.
@kenvix #4 Integrated graphics switching issue, the graphics card will not switch after the software starts.

So, the software opened with the integrated graphics will continue to be rendered with the integrated graphics even if an external screen is connected, and the data backflow will cause it to be even more laggy.
